title: ORD | Zurich
description: Join us for a day of plenary lectures on topics such as the importance of ORD, IP and licensing, and reproducible research. In the workshops, you'll have the opportunity to learn about Renku for reproducibility, Git for version control, and OpenBIS for collaborating with data and electronic lab notebooks. In the second session, explore licenses for AI models with BigRAIL, advanced Git techniques, and best practices for managing sensitive data with OpenBIS. Don't miss this chance to enhance your knowledge and skills in ORD principles and apply them to your research!

timeline.title: Research and Free Software
timeline.description:
Software is deeply involved in all aspects of our lives, and it is important that this technology empowers rather than restricts us. Free Software, also known as Open Source Software, gives everybody the rights to use, understand, adapt, and share software. The principles of Free Software are also well aligned with the basic principles of science, in particular Open Science.
The four freedoms allow sharing of knowledge and the demand for reproducibility of results. Nevertheless, Free Software is still rather the exception than the rule for the majority of scientific domains. In this session we will discuss the benefits and challenges of Free Software and Open Science.

speaker.name: Alexander Sander
speaker.long_description: Alexander has studied politics in Marburg, Germany. He has been an MEP Assistant in Brussels and the General Manager of Digitale Gesellschaft e.V. in Berlin. Furthermore he is the founder of NoPNR!, a campaign against the retention of travel data. He is an expert on digital rights and this capacity also a member of several advisory boards. He is also a member of several other associations that advocate for digital rights. Alexander consults national and European institutions, administrations and organisations, is available as an expert to the media and gives lectures and workshops at international conferences and events.

keypoints: Free Software plays an important role in research, be it a generic tools or as a product for research
Free Software and Open Science share common values and goals
The use of Free Software creates innovation and trust

timeline.title: Journey towards Open Science and Open Research Data
timeline.description:
Over the last years the Open Science movement has significantly grown, with the aim to make scientific progress more transparent, efficient, and accessible. Open Science is fostered by UNESCO, the EU Commission and most national funding agencies and academic institutions. An important element of Open Science is the wider dissemination of scientific datasets, also known as Open Research Data (ORD). ORD comes with the requirement to publish research data and make them openly accessible, whenever possible. Open data need to adhere to the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) principles, so that the scientific community can validate published results and build on them for further discoveries that can foster human progress.
To achieve this goal, managing research data from the moment they are generated is of outmost importance. Samples, materials, and equipment used in experiments, experimental procedures, codes used for data processing and analysis, models, datasets: all must be accurately documented. Moreover, all data that are generated in a research project need to be annotated with appropriate and sufficient metadata, that would make them reusable by other experts in the field, without the need to contact the authors, as it is still often the case.
In this talk we will look at some of the tools that enable efficient research data management and reproducible research results, thus paving the way to open FAIR data and Open Science.

speaker.name: Caterina Barillari
speaker.long_description: Caterina holds a degree in Chemistry and Pharmaceutical Technology from the University of Milan (IT) and a PhD in Computational Chemistry from the University of Southampton (UK). After two postdocs in cheminformatics at the CNRS in Strasbourg (FR) and at the Institute of Cancer Research UK, she joined ETH Zürich in 2011. She currently manages the Research Data Management services provided by the Scientific IT Services of ETH Zürich for the academic community of ETH Zürich and within Switzerland.

keypoints: Research Data Management (RDM) is a prerequisite for publishing and sharing data according to the FAIR data principles.

Planning how to annotate, store, back up data and which tools to use, needs to be done at the beginning of a research project. The plan can be adapted according to the progress of the research project.
RDM must be an integral part of a researcher’s daily work.

workshops.title: Introduction to Renku and how it can help you with reproducibility and collaboration in your research
workshops.description: Renku provides tools that foster reproducibility and collaboration in research projects. If you write and run code to analyze data, Renku can help you track your work, run your models, share results and collaborate with your colleagues. The workshop has two parts: a general introduction of Renku and the vision behind the project, and a demo. The demo is intended to show that with minimal effort Renku allows you to not only track and replicate your work, but also do so in a reproducible environment where you and your colleagues can explore, run, test and improve upon the work you have done.

speaker.name: Tasko Olevski
speaker.long_description: Tasko is a software engineer at the Swiss Data Science Center. He has worked on many components of the Renku platform and has been also involved in the operations of several different production-grade Renku deployments. Prior to joining the Swiss Data Science Center Tasko was working as an environmental consultant focusing on ambient air quality modeling. His degree is in chemical engineering, but his passion is writing code.

keypoints: Learn about Renku and its key features and benefits
Understand how Renku can help with reproducibility
Understand how Renku can foster collaboration between researchers
Understand how you can start to use Renku for your research

workshops.title: Introduction to Active Research Data Management with the ETH Zurich ELN/LIMS openBIS
workshops.description:
Active research data management involves the ongoing organization, storage, and sharing of research data throughout the entire data lifecycle. This approach allows researchers to maintain the integrity of their data and ensure that it is available for analysis, interpretation, and future use. With active research data management, researchers can enhance the reproducibility of their work, facilitate collaboration, and accelerate scientific discovery.
The workshop will cover:
  • Intro on FAIR data principles
  • Intro on openBIS: structure and major functionality
  • User cases

speaker.name: Rostyslav Kuzyakiv
speaker.long_description: Senior Biomedical Data Management Expert / Data Scientist with a background in general medicine, biology, and expertise in bioinformatics, data management, and digital health applications. Currently, consulting and assisting the ETHZ scientist community in developing and implementing various data management solutions based on FAIR data principles and major protocols of the Swiss Personalized Health Network.

keypoints: Consistency: to ensure reliable and reproducible results. Any deviation from the standard protocols and procedures can introduce variability and affect the accuracy of the results.
Quality Control: to ensure the quality of the data generated. Can help to minimize errors and ensure that data is of high quality.
Traceability: to ensure that the samples can be traced back to their source, and that the results can be verified if necessary.
Compliance: to ensure that researchers are following the necessary guidelines and regulations.
Collaboration: to ensure the reproducibility and validity of the research.

workshops.title: Ethical aspects in open licensing
workshops.description: Again and again there are discussions about the openness of licenses with regard to ethical considerations. Often the freedom to use the software for any purpose is questioned. In the field of AI research, there has recently been a well-known licence that restricts the use of the software in order to minimise its harmful effects. But does this make sense and is it successful, and what problems does it cause? The workshop will discuss the meaning and consequences of such ethical licences.
keypoints: The freedom to use the software for any purpose is important
A licence won’t fix ethical problems

workshops.title: Secure handling of sensitive data in research
workshops.description:
Research with sensitive data (e.g. personal data such as medical records) requires special cybersecurity and data protection measures to ensure the confidentiality of data and to protect the privacy of individuals. What are sensitive data in Research? What laws and regulations must be followed? What are the implication of non-compliance? I am a researcher - how do I translate and integrate laws, regulations and cybersecurity into my day-to-day research practice? Let's try to bring light to these questions. This workshop will be focused on:
  • research on sensitive data (sensitive personal data),
  • data privacy and protection: legislation and cybersecurity awareness,
  • data classification: strictly confidential and confidential data vs. internal and public data,
  • Leonhard Med, ETH Zurich: Swiss secure, powerful and versatile Scientific IT Platform for research on and with confidential data,
  • “best practices” for FAIRness of sensitive research data: secure handling of sensitive research data along the entire data lifecycle, from data collection, data management and analysis to publication in repositories and long-term preservation.

speaker.name: Diana Coman Schmid
speaker.long_description: Diana Coman Schmid is Service Manager of the Personalized Health Data Services at the Scientific IT Services of ETH Zurich. Alongside, Diana is an enthusiastic giver and enjoys sharing knowledge and know-how around digitalization, cybersecurity and FAIRness of sensitive personal data. Diana did her PhD at ETH Zurich in Molecular Biology and expanded her expertise with a Degree in Advanced Applied Statistics at ETH. Diana is an expert in IT and Data Services for Personalized Health, Bioinformatics, Applied Statistics and Biological Networks. Working now at the interface between IT, Data and Medicine, Diana’s commitment is to be an active driver in making Data Driven Personalized Health becoming common practice. For this, Diana together the team at the Scientific IT Services of ETH Zurich develop and operate secure, scalable and versatile scientific Data and IT services for researchers working with sensitive personal data at ETH and at Swiss national level.

keypoints: have a good understanding of data protection and privacy issues when dealing with sensitive data in research projects
have the necessary knowledge to conduct research respecting both legislation as well as information security requirements
be able to identify if research data classifies as strictly confidential or confidential
be able to apply “best practices” for FAIRness of sensitive research data
be aware of available secure scientific IT infrastructures for sensitive research data
have the information needed for writing a data management plan for sensitive research data
